hints_html:
Recall that the Laplace transform for a function f(t) is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(f(t))=\int_0^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt\end{aligned}\]

How do we integrate a piecewise function?
hints_latex: How do we integrate a piecewise function?
hints_raw:
Recall that the Laplace transform for a function f(t) is

:<math>
\mathcal{L}(f(t))=\int_0^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt
</math>
How do we integrate a piecewise function?
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
The Laplace transform, F(s), for a function f(t) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} F(s)=\mathcal{L}(f(t))=\int_0^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt.\end{aligned}\]

Since our function is piecewise defined we can split up the integral and write

\[\begin{aligned} F(s)&=\int_0^1f(t)dt+\int_1^2f(t)\exp(-st)dt+\int_2^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt\\ F(s)&=\int_0^10dt+2\pi\int_1^2\exp(-st)dt+\pi\int_2^\infty\exp(-st)dt.\end{aligned}\]

The first integral is just zero. For the second integral we get,

\[\begin{aligned} 2\pi\int_1^2\exp(-st)dt=-\left.\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-st)\right|_1^2=-\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)+\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-s).\end{aligned}\]

For the third integral we get

\[\begin{aligned} \pi\int_2^\infty\exp(-st)dt=-\left.\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-st)\right|_2^\infty=\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-2s).\end{aligned}\]

Adding the two integrals together we get

\[\begin{aligned} F(s)=-\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)+\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-s)+\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)=\frac{\pi}{s}\left(2\exp(-s)-\exp(-2s)\right).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The Laplace transform, F(s), for a function f(t) is given by

:<math>
F(s)=\mathcal{L}(f(t))=\int_0^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt.
</math>

Since our function is piecewise defined we can split up the integral and write

:<math>
\begin{align}
F(s)&=\int_0^1f(t)dt+\int_1^2f(t)\exp(-st)dt+\int_2^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt\\
F(s)&=\int_0^10dt+2\pi\int_1^2\exp(-st)dt+\pi\int_2^\infty\exp(-st)dt.
\end{align}
</math>

The first integral is just zero.  For the second integral we get,

:<math>
2\pi\int_1^2\exp(-st)dt=-\left.\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-st)\right|_1^2=-\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)+\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-s).
</math>

For the third integral we get
:<math>
\pi\int_2^\infty\exp(-st)dt=-\left.\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-st)\right|_2^\infty=\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-2s).
</math>

Adding the two integrals together we get

:<math>
F(s)=-\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)+\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-s)+\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)=\frac{\pi}{s}\left(2\exp(-s)-\exp(-2s)\right).
</math>
statement_html:
Given the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(t) = \begin{cases} 0, & t<1 \\ 2\pi, & 1 \leq t < 2 \\ \pi, & t \geq 2 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

(a) Find the Laplace transform of f(t).
statement_raw:
Given the function

:<math>
f(t) = \begin{cases}
0, & t<1 \\
2\pi, & 1 \leq t < 2 \\
\pi, & t \geq 2
\end{cases}
</math>

'''(a)''' Find the Laplace transform of ''f(t)''.
